utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Big Eye this is Cobra zero-six, just entered Indian country, approaching wave .4, request confirmation to engage target on first approach.

utterance.speaker: BIG EYE
utterance.content: Roger Cobra zero-six, Big Eye waiting for confirmation as well.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: If you wait any longer Big Eye, we're not going to have a choice in the matter, I can't exactly do a U-turn here.

utterance.speaker: BIG EYE
utterance.content: Roger that, Cobra, hold for confirmation.

utterance.speaker: MAN
utterance.content: Captain Cooper, are you okay? What happened? You weren't answering.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Because the damn com cord got disconnected! You spend a billion dollars on the avionics and don't bother to check the com connection?

utterance.speaker: MAN
utterance.content: No, I checked that twice before you got in.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: And the next time you ask us to test a prototype, it'd be nice if your direction gyro didn't spin like a top when I'm supposed to be 500 feet off the floor.

utterance.speaker: MAN
utterance.content: I'm sorry. I'll go review the simulation, see if I can figure out what went wrong.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Who is this man?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: C'mon, take a shot. I'm not going to fire you every time you get a wrong answer.
Neville Chamberlain.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You're fired. Does this man look like he's ceding Czechoslovakia to a fascist dictatorship?
It's Buddy Ebsen, the actor, he's dead. Why are we...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Buddy Ebsen was the original tin man in the Wizard of Oz, for a day. He was diagnosed allergic to the aluminium dust in the make-up. His lungs failed, he nearly died, question is, why?
Didn't you just say he was allergic?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You may not have legs, but you've got ears, I suggest you use them. I said he was diagnosed allergic. Since we are currently short exactly one interesting patient, we are going to figure out what really happened to Buddy Ebsen in 1938. Now on one hand he's not getting deader, on the other hand your jobs hang in the balance. So...

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: House?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I want seven alternate diagnoses when I get back.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Did you forget how to count to three?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I've got a budget for three, doesn't mean I can only hire three.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Actually that's exactly what it means.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I cut the permanent salaries by 10 percent, over 3 years that'll more than make up for the breakage on the 27 that I'm going to weed out over the next few weeks.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: There's forty people in there.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Row D, you're fired. I didn't actually count all the resumes.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: This is stupid, you can't manage that many people, you're just going to keep weeding them out arbitrarily.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Sure. and having them sitting in my office schmoozing about their favourite Algerian surfing movies, that's a much better system. Wait a sec. Were you in Row D?
Yes.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: My apologies, my boss says I'm being arbitrary and stupid. Row D is not fired, Row C is fired.
Great, thank you.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: See? That was not arbitrary. Well, I'd love to chat but I've been paged. That's interesting, apparently paged myself.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If you have a resumé there I'm not interested, but I wouldn't mind hearing how you got my pager number.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: It's not a resumé. 50,000 dollars.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Does One-eyed Nicky want me to run that to Jimmy the Nose?

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: It's for my medical bills. I need you to find out what's wrong with me.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Insurance is usually cheaper than that. Cash means there's something to hide.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: I'm a captain in the Air Force about to start a new assignment. NASA's astronaut training program.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I discovered salt and created FM radio.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Something is wrong. With my eyes, my ears.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well if it's fixable the Air Force will do it for free. If not, doesn't matter.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: There are 100 applicants ready to take my place who don't need to be fixed. I need to do this off the books. I did the research, you're the best, you break rules, and you don't care about anyone except yourself.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well let’s say that's true. You get a new job, the hospital gets a nice wad of cash, what do I get?

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: I crashed a flight simulator, because I started to hear, with my eyes.
The aluminium could have been tainted...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Don't care. New patient. 30 year old female, with synaesthesia. New rules. You generate a lab report – You shred it. X-ray - You melt it. No notes, no records, nothing. As far as you're concerned the patient is Osama Bin Laden and everyone not in this room is Delta Force. Any questions?
We're protecting Osama Bin Laden?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It's a metaphor. Get used to it. Any more questions?
And you're not even going to tell us her name?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You think her name might be connected to what's wrong with her? Here's Osama! Now you all have numbers so we're going to do this, alphabetically. 8, 15 and 5.
Is the synaesthesia new?

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Yes.
Any history of similar symptoms or psychiatric...

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: No, nothing.
Are you on any prescription meds or use any other drugs?

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: No.
Should we trust her answers?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: What, you think I'd pull you off Buddy Ebsen just for a junkie?
Can we trust your answers?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You have got to trust someone, right?
No. Has anyone close to you been sick lately? A family member, a co worker?

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: No, not that I'm aware of.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Two down, Kitty Carlisle?
You spend much time above 20,000 feet?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Why would you ask that?
People who fly are immobile for long periods. Could be a leg clot that embolised to the brain through a PFO.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That's an unusual choice.
Well like you said, you wouldn't interrupt Buddy with anything that wasn't.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: The patient is a frequent flyer. 13, 32, 39, get Osama an EEG, MRI and an angiogram. How many of you think that Oswald acted alone?
If by alone you mean that he was unaware that the CIA...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Oh shut up. Split yourselves into 2 groups, test her blood, test her stool. Who likes the designated hitter? You're wrong, you're lucky you're not fired. 2 more groups, LP and cultures. Who doesn't know what a designated hitter is? Okay, here is her address, I want you to break in, find out what she's hiding.
Why don't we just ask the patient for the key?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well, if we could find out what she's hiding just by asking we'd have to redefine hiding. You want to live in this country, learn the language.
What do you want the rest of us to do?
Thirty people for three openings and "I want you to wash my car." This is not why I busted my ass in med school!
So we spend a half an hour cleaning a car, big deal.
It's demeaning.
Work is demeaning? You're too good for this?
Now don't give me that honest day’s labour crap. We all went to med school so we wouldn't have to do an honest day's labour.
What about an honest hour's labour? In exchange we get a shot at learning from one of the best diagnosticians in the world.

No, we don't. If we did we'd be one of the ones drawing blood or checking for toxins. We're done. He's just not going to cut us loose until we've dusted his shelves and starched his shirt. I'm out of here. Who's with me?
Are we sure he wasn't joking? Maybe this is just a test.
Everything's a joke and everything's a test and he wants us to do it. C'mon, get up here.
Well, I could try but I pulled a muscle in 1987.
I didn't waste two years repeating medical school to be arrested and deported.
Why did they make you repeat? Not enough gym credits?
According to the state of New Jersey, medical schools in my country suffer from not being from this country.
You know if you get it open you're going to have to come down and let me in?
Or, you could just wait out here. This is a competition.
You change your mind?
No.
Then why are you here?
Never intended to quit.
Then why did you...
Intended to get everyone else to quit. Get off the car.
I need to clean it. WE need to clean it.
I stole his keys. We'll take it to a car wash. He's got people breaking into a woman's apartment, obviously respecting personal property isn't one of the rules.
I told the super I was worried about my niece, she hasn't been answering the telephone. Nice guy. Two daughters in Mount Holyoke.
No evidence of clots and other than elevated red blood cell count, ah, the ah, blood work was unremarkable.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Got a problem with the naked female form?
Not at all.
Maybe she's just not used to seeing it spooning with the naked dolphin form.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: That's not a dolphin, it's a porpoise. There is a difference you know. Salary for one thing.
You want us to give you a minute?
A high red blood cell count likely means...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Carbon monoxide poisoning.
There are a lot of different explanations for elevated red blood cells.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Yeah well which one fits best with the damaged flue that your competitors found in the gas fireplace in Osama's cave.
Car's clean.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Did you just see a blond guy with a pretentious accent?
Can't see an accent.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Good point. Can I have my car keys back? Give me the car keys, put the patient in a hyperbaric chamber and no more prime numbers for you. Thank you.
The high pressure and oxygen will flush the carbon monoxide from your system. This much oxygen for too long can have some toxic effects so we'll do this in cycles.
Can I talk to you for a second? You're working that thing all the time, is everything all right? We're supposed to be watching her heart rate and blood pressure.
Yeah, I was until you pulled me over here. I'm sending out a consult on another patient.
Okay.
What? I'm not quitting my old job until I'm sure I've got a new one.
I didn't say anything.
You had a look.
Yeah, I did. Sorry.
Hey I think she's having a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: No I just feel a little funny.
Tachy-arrhythmia.
Call a code.
Nothing.
V-fib. Well where the hell's...
Clear.
Are you crazy? You can't use those we're in a hyperbaric...
Clear.
She's on fire!
Her heart's beating.
And we are so fired.
We've started her on nitro and blood thinners. Electrolytes and post-arrest EKG were normal, the attack was not caused by the procedure.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So what does cause synaesthesia, high red blood cell count and heart attack?
Aren't we going to discuss what caused the sudden appearance of burnt flesh? He brought charged paddles into an oxygenated room.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: And you didn't stop him. Means either you thought it was a chance worth taking, making you a hypocrite, or you thought he'd fail, making you a cut throat little pixie. What causes...

utterance.speaker: 15A
utterance.content: Takayasu’s syndrome.

utterance.speaker: 15B
utterance.content: Not without a rash and a fever. It's got to be Whipple's.

utterance.speaker: 15A
utterance.content: No way, you ever see Whipple's without abdominal pain?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stop it! This argument is distracting every male and lesbian here. You're both right, in the sense that you've convinced me that you're both wrong.
What about cardiomyopathy? Structural abnormality causes the heart attack and throws clots to the brain, leading to synaesthesia.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How old are you?
I'm 21. Unless it's relevant.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay, Scooter. Do a trans-esophageal echo, and since the positive divisors of 26 are 2 and 13 have them assist. The rest of you, go to the cafeteria and document 10 things that could cause infection. Each.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: I wouldn't. Someone named 17 thinks there could be Listeria in the cream cheese.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: 17's a stupid number. What's Chase doing here?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You saw Chase?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Last night, outside my office.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: That's interesting.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It's more curious than actually...

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Chase took a job at the Mayo Clinic in Arizona. A week ago. Interesting... It wasn't Foreman or Cameron you saw, but Chase, the one you fired.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Not interesting. Someone who looked like someone I used to know walked by my office.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: It's always interesting when repressed guilt starts un-repressing itself.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: The only thing I feel guilty for is this.
We're going to feed this endoscope down your esophagus, try to find where your heart might be damaged. It's going to feel uncomfortable but just keep swallowing, I promise you'll be fine.
She's ready.
Go ahead, take a whack.
Right. So if we don't find anything House blames me.
Or you find something, get a gold star.
Why don't you want to do it?
House isn't going to be impressed by a grey hair doing his 10,000th echo.
So you're just being altruistic?
That makes you suspicious. Doctor?
Call me 13. I'm not getting invested.
Her heart's structurally sound. No clots, no valvular defects, no wall motion abnormalities.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Got that from structurally sound.

utterance.speaker: 15A
utterance.content: What did she say?
Structurally sound.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I assume you're not all walking with me to tell me that you found nothing.
It showed a short burst in the atrium...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay, who's next?
Showed a short burst of atrial flutter, I ran a rhythm strip twice and got the same results.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stop. Okay. Here's how we diagnose in transit. I lead, you draft, I move, you move, I stop, you stop. Got it?
Flutter could mean hormone overproduction, we should...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Wait a sec, why did you do the test? I gave it to Scooter.
We didn't think it mattered.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It doesn't. It matters that you let her. Okay. 10, 24, 39 run a TRH stimulation test for hyperthyroidism.
That could cause another heart attack.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Proving her first attack was caused by her thyroid. Which is kind of the point, right? Uh ah ah ah ah! I ride alone.

The hormone stimulates your thyroid, don't worry if you get flushed or you start to sweat, it means the thyroid's working. And if you want I can remove that mole. I'm a plastic surgeon, you're allowed a little vanity.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: I'm fine with the way I look.
Good for you. Although I do find it a bit odd that someone so self-assured doesn't want her doctors to find out what's wrong with her.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: What are you talking about, why else am I here?
You're jerking us around. You're handcuffing us with all these restrictions.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: I'm feeling warm.
Her pulse is 120, stop pushing. If House thought this would handicap us he wouldn't have taken the case.
Or maybe that's why he took the case, he wants to see if we can get it out of her on our own.
What did you find in her home?

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: You were in my home?
Nothing.
Travel pictures, year book, her name on an employment slip?
We weren't checking for that stuff, okay? Obviously House didn't want us to.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: You're going to... You're going to out me, aren't you? You're going to ruin everything.
Nobody's trying to do anything. Just relax.
This is not a normal response to the test. Pulse and BP are too high.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Get away from me. Get away from me. Don't touch me.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Paging me during Judge Judy, not the best way to win my affections.
She had another episode of synaesthesia, it set off a psychotic attack and now she ran in there and must've jammed something in the handles.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So you called me, the guy with one good leg and zero leverage.
We break that door down, security shows up, and her name goes in a file.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well luckily, violence is not the last resort. Extortion is. So go ahead, extort her.
If you don't open this door, we're going to break it down.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Clever. An appeal to her deep concern for hospital property. Let's see how that works.
If you don't open this door, you're going to die.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Go away!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You seem to be getting to her.
She doesn't care if she dies.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You think she wants to die?
No, but I think she only wants to live under certain circumstances. Open up or I blab your secret to everyone.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: You don't know anything.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I do.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Anybody think that a sedative might...
I'm trying.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Who's that? Who is she?
Osama Bin Laden.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Who is she?
Is she okay?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: She's stable. Who is she?
What did House tell you?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: That she is on the run from an international crime syndicate.
That's what he told us.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: House may be your boss, but I'm House's boss. You want to work here, I better be okay with it.
Honestly, he didn't tell us anything about who she was, or what she...
Her name's Greta Cooper. Wants to be an astronaut. Doesn't want NASA to know her brain's getting her ears confused with her eyes. I went through her mail.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You're a virus, House, now instead of one liability I've got 20.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Apparently only 19. Which number was it?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: From now on everything you do gets charted. With pen, on paper, in a binder that says "Princeton Plainsboro Teaching Hospital" on the cover.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Mom!

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: If you want to run something through the labs, I get a copy. If you do scans, I get a copy. If you THINK about doing scans, I get a copy.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You know my current thoughts, right? I don't have to put those on paper.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Three issues. One. Number 10, you're fired.
She told you?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well, it had to be someone who went to her home. Number 26 is half asleep, missed his afternoon nap. Obviously he doesn't feel guilt. Number 2 is here on a visa, she can't jeopardise...
You can't know!

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: And that chick's been pointing at you since I walked in. Issue two. What causes synaesthesia, high RBC, tachy-arrhythmia, and panic attacks?
Slight glucose elevation. That says thyroid.
Baseline thyrotropin's 1.1.
Whatever. Her thyroid's working.
What about her liver? Original A.L.T. levels weren't abnormal but were near the edge.
She has patient data on her PDA.
I do not.
I saw the lab values, you said we couldn't write anything down.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I also said I wanted answers.
Liver cancer's the most likely. Paraneoplastic syndrome. We need to do an MRI.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Which brings us to issue three.
You're saying we can write stuff down?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: To you, I'm saying you're fired. To everyone else, I'm...
But you said specifically...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I hate tattle tales.
She tattled on 10.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Now you tattled twice. Issue three. C'mon, let’s go. Issue three, how do we do tests when we can't do tests?
Dr. Cuddy didn't say we can't do tests, she said that we have to chart.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: If we chart, then we won't get consent. So we can't.
The patient's life may depend on her consenting.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Her dreams depend on her not consenting. So, how do we do tests when we can't do tests? You've got an hour.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How do you scan a liver without scanning a liver? And what's Cameron doing here?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Interesting. So you're seeing Cameron now?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No. Not interesting because not seeing. Saw. My patient won't consent to MRIs or ultrasounds, and you've dealt with more liver cancer than anyone else here.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: So you want me to share the secret scanning techniques I learned in Nepal? Unfortunately, the monks made me swear a blood oath. Where was she?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: In the lobby. I guess we could palpate the area around the liver.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Which won't work unless the tumour's enormous, which you KNOW, which means you're here because these visions are freaking you out.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: She had blonde hair, why would I hallucinate that?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Yes. Yes, why are you merging Cameron and Chase? We should find out before the next time you see her when she'll be black.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Mm-hmm, because, of course it's scientifically impossible for a person to go back and visit somewhere they worked.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: No. But since she's not a dead cat, it is scientifically impossible for her to be in two places at once.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Physics joke. Don't hear enough of those.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: She just called me from Arizona. Notice the area code – 480. They put an offer on a place in Scottsdale. Do you want to talk or should I? I guess we could both talk. Although they're engaged and if you're staying in touch, you might want to buy them... Maybe it's not repressed guilt, Maybe it's just panic. Right now you've got enough fellows to build a rail road. But you're going to have to narrow that room full of numbers down to three people.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Any chance you could turn this creative brilliance towards my patient's liver?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: I think you're going to choose people for reasons that have nothing to do with their skills. I think you're going to choose people just because you can't stand them. Because if you like them, well, that's just, stressful.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Stress... I like it.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: We need to stress the patient's liver.

utterance.speaker: 15B
utterance.content: You mean make her sick?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I mean make her sick in a specific way. If her liver's given to malfunctioning, we make it malfunction.

utterance.speaker: 15B
utterance.content: Are we on the other side of wrong here? Don't we have an ethics board that we should consult or...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I fired you.
He fired you. You're number 6.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I approve of your shamelessness. You're still fired. So how do we stress her liver?

utterance.speaker: 15B
utterance.content: Lying and paperwork I get, shutting down organs I think...
We could give her intravenous Vitamin D and stick her in a tanning booth. If she goes into a coma, we know it's a metabolic problem.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Nice. But Vitamin D's metabolised by the liver and kidneys. It wouldn't tell us which one's screwed up.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I like you, number 9.
You wanted to see me?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You a Mormon? You're wearing a ring from Brigham Young. Or did your folks just do the lawns?
The church has a very progressive attitude toward racial equality.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Don't care. Actually I'm thanking God. You're the only non-drinker we've got. We need a control group to establish whether the liver's deterioration is within normal range. Got a big drinker, medium drinker, now I got a no-drinker.
Just do an MRI.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You really think the guy who created heaven and earth cares what you put in your digestive tract?
Her dream shouldn't outrank my religious belief.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Why not? Her dream might come true. All life is sacred, right?
We're not saving her life, we're doing a diagnostic test. Not even a real diagnostic test.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Well that fake test, might really save her life. Would you pull an ass out of a pit on the Sabbath? Would you or would you not pull an ass out of a pit on the Sabbath?
Fine. I'll do it.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Why'd you have to pick tequila? I assume a single malt would have worked just as well.
Wasn't our choice.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay. Two minutes and we go round number 5. So tell me about the magic underwear.
Is that why you're here?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I'm the big drinker, doing my part for science. The interesting question is why your religious beliefs are suddenly less important than her dreams.
You're reversing your argument?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I know what I believe. I'm just not quite sure what you believe.
Well, LDS doesn't try to dictate every detail of our lives. When a situation isn't clear, we're encouraged to make our own decisions.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: But your judgment was to say no. You used my judgment.
You made a good argument.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Rational arguments don't usually work on religious people. Otherwise there would be no religious people.
You're an atheist.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Only on Christmas and Easter. The rest of the time, it doesn't really matter.
Where's the fun in that? A finite, un-mysterious universe...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It's not about fun! It's about the truth.
The truth is, we're having this debate because you want to figure something out about me. What do you got so far?
Greta. Greta!
She can't breathe. We need to intubate.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: No.
At least oxygen.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: NASA will need to know why.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: I checked the tests you ordered.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Did you just see Foreman?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You measured the density of her teeth.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It's a shortcut test for hypercalcaemia. You had to have just passed him.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: So you suspected hypercalcaemia from her complete lack of broken bones. Is that why you also ran three tox screens?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Patient might've been sneaking uppers. He was in a white coat, did you hire him back?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Foreman is running the diagnostic department at New York Mercy. Have you been drinking?
She was having trouble breathing. Refused oxygen and intubation.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So you put her on a treadmill.
Records will show that we gave her oxygen as a part of a routine cardio stress test. She gets to breathe, your boss gets her paperwork.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Whose idea was that?
It was a joint decision.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It never is. So how old were you when your brother left home?
Why do you think that I...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Why aren't you answering? Did your mother initiate the divorce?
We should probably focus on what's wrong with her lungs.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Are you a Wiccan?
She really can't breathe.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay, hold still.
What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Auscultatory percussion. If you have a good ear, you can... You didn't have a lot of friends because you chose...
You can hear while you're talking?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You can detect not only structural details, but small, deep masses. Game's over. You either have lung cancer or tuberous sclerosis. We need to cut you open and biopsy...

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: That'll... Leave a scar... NASA doctors will see, they'll, they'll know.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I never opened for Springsteen or slept with Barbara Feldon. You can live for years without dreams. Without lungs...

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Find a way.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Okay. As long you keep saying it strongly, you won't die.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: Find... A way.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How do we force a patient into surgery? Texas bag scam? Saratoga wire? Paris exposition trip?
The problem's not the surgery, it's the scars. And we have a plastic surgeon here who can hide them.
Not that well. NASA's going to check every cranny.
She'll sue.
For what? Making it harder for her to lie to the government?
Uh, we don't need to hide them. We give her elective cosmetic surgery. The incisions will give us access to her lungs and she's got an innocent explanation for the scars.
You mean like liposuction?
No, no. Those incisions are too far from the lungs. We-we don't subtract, we add. Turn her B's into C's.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It's a myth that fake hooters blow up at high altitude, she'll be fine. Just think of it as one giant rack for mankind.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: I fought for years to be taken seriously.
Trust me, you'll be taken more seriously. Just sign the form.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: This'll make me a joke, there's got to be another way.
I've known a few people who had dreams. One thing they all had in common was, they got laughed at, and they didn't care.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You bumped a splenectomy for a boob job?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Would you condemn this woman to a life where people look at her face when they talk to her?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: You don't explain this, I'll cancel the surgery.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Can I explain why you're here?

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Think I just told you why I...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I scheduled a diagnostic patient for a boob job, which is ridiculous. So obviously you had to confront me.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: With you so far.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: But I'm going to give you a reason.

utterance.speaker: CUDDY
utterance.content: Not a good one.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No. Not even close to a good one. But here's the drag from your point of view. My explanation will make sense. Not to the board, not to a judge, but to you. So you'll let me do it. Then you're going to have to sit next to me at the administrative hearing. Don't you have better things to do? It's in the best interests of the patient.
Trochar's in. You're good to go.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Deflate the lung.
There, a cyst.
Cysts, I count three of them.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Probably the same if not more on the left lung. Okay, so what's been working overtime to kill Miss Bin Laden?
We know her name now.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Yeah, but I forgot it. Say the magic word and get immunity from the next challenge.
Alveolar hydatid disease. Hits all the organs.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: She would've had multiple seizures by now.
Pulmonary Langerhans.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Wouldn't explain the red blood cells. C'mon. Cysts, synaesthesia, heart attack. You guys have gotten...

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. Raises red blood cell count, causes masses on the organs. One of the masses is a pheochromocytoma. It'd cause neurologic episodes and a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Do you see a blond guy who still has peach fuzz standing up there? This is a closed procedure, gallery's off limits.

utterance.speaker: CHASE
utterance.content: Not to the surgical staff.
You going to hire that guy instead of us.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Not a chance. I love you guys. Dig out the cysts, histology to confirm Von Hippel-Lindau. Don't forget her chesticles.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Calling Arizona, that was a very nice touch.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You do have residual...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Not only do I not have residual feelings, I didn't even have primary feelings.

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: You freaked...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You lied!

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: Because you knew it meant...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It meant nothing! I saw him because he was there. Did Cameron follow her beshert to the surgery department?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: I think Chase followed her. She's been a senior attending in the E.R. the last three weeks. A blonde senior attending, to be accurate.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Foreman. Is he back in neurology?

utterance.speaker: WILSON
utterance.content: He's at New York Mercy, he's been there a month. Did you SEE Foreman?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: So, I'm cured.
Greta, you need to come clean to NASA.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: You said you got all the cysts.
They could re-emerge.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: I'll go to radiology clinics. I'll get regular screenings.
If something happened while you're up there, you'd be playing Russian roulette with...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Relax. She doesn't have to tell and neither do you. Turns out that NASA doctors even know where the hyphen in Von Hippel-Lindau goes.

utterance.speaker: GRETA
utterance.content: You called them?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I'm not an idiot. Those shuttles fly over New Jersey.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: So here we are. The big moment. Which of you gets to live to be abused another day. And which of you goes home and rationalises being fired as character building? Following numbers, thanks for playing. 21, 19, 8, 34, 17, 29, 5, 36, 2... Rest of you, 8:00 A.M. Sharp. I'll be in sometime between 10:00 and 3:00. But 26, stick around awhile.
I did nothing wrong.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Lots of people did nothing wrong.
Other people screwed up. I never even...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Other people took chances. 26.
Buddy Ebsen actually was allergic to...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. How old are you?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You don't think it's relevant?
I'll likely have less time to use the skills you teach us, but I don't think that's significant to you.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: How about the fact that you never went to medical school? Which is why you let the unlucky number do the trans echo. At least you're ethically unethical.
Thirty years I worked in the Columbia med school admissions office. Audited all the classes. Most of them more than once. I just never got a diploma.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You had to know I'd find out sooner or later.
I know you break rules. I thought maybe you'd break one for me.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I can't hire you as a doctor. But you can still tell me what you think. You can also fetch me coffee, pick up my dry-cleaning, until I can decide whether or not to keep you.
So I'm playing this whole game to be like... Your secretary?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Assistant sounds marginally less demeaning.
It's not my dream job.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Actually it is. It's just not your dream title.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Three weeks. For someone who never misses something small, you missed something big.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You're an idiot.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: The hair, where I'm working, or both?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: The hair makes you look like a hooker. I like it. Pulling pieces of windshield out of car accident victims and reattaching fingertips sliced off cutting bagels. At least Chase's move is only one step down.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: I can do good here. Get it out of my system. Why'd you rat your patient out to NASA?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I don't know who's been gossiping about ethics instead of sex, but I hope they've already been fired. Which number was it?

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Greta.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Number!

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: No number. The patient. How do you think she got your pager number? She came into the E.R. didn't want to talk...

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: I didn't rat her out.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: You--lied?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Suppose I should tell her that before she keys my car.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Why lie?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: Had to stop some leaky faucets.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: What did it matter?

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: It was no one's business.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: She's going to be the safest astronaut up there. Certainly more vigilant than the guy next to her who's got no clue about the aneurysm in his head ready to pop.

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: HOUSE
utterance.content: You got a better reason?

utterance.speaker: CAMERON
utterance.content: You couldn't kill her dream.
